projectDesc.p: WorldViews is a multilingual‚ digital resource for primary sources containing excerpts from textbooks from around the world on topics that are of global‚ transnational and interregional relevance. The selected source material from textbooks reveals how the individual countries position themselves in the world and how they portray other countries and their histories. Academic contributions provide more in-depth interpretations of the source material as well as information on the national education and textbook systems and background information on the history of education.

samplingDecl.p: Text excerpts are chosen because they are striking in terms of representation interpretive framework and/or perspective. They are portrayals that are published in widely distributed textbooks or stand out due to their unique standpoint. They are collected by project partners or the editorial team‚ given academic context and translated into German and English paying particular attention to the cultural and historical context of the source text.

abstract.p: According to the subtitle, this book was created for elementary school and corresponded to the official curriculum.

The text deals with the end of the first Spanish settlement in the territory of modern Argentina. According to the text, the chief of an indigenous tribe wanted to capture a Spanish woman. For this reason, he attacked and destroyed the settlement.

The text deals with the end of Sancti Spiritus, the first Spanish settlement in the territory of modern Argentina, around 1530. According to the text, chief Mangoré of the local Timbu tribe wanted to capture a Spanish woman, Lucía Miranda. To this end, he snuck into Sancti Spiritus at night with his men, kidnapped the women and children, killed the men and burnt down the settlement. The few survivors, so the story goes, subsequently left the location and retreated to Brazil. The exercise following the text aims to recap the depicted (alleged) facts.

list.item: The colony of Sancti Spiritus, the first settlement of the Spaniards by La Plata river, did not last long.

There was a very beautiful woman, Lucía Miranda, whom chief Mangoré, leader of a Timbu tribe, wanted to take into his possession; to this end, he pretended to bring supplies and entered the Fortress at night with all of his people, while the Spaniards were sleeping, seized the women and children, killed the men and burnt down the fortress.
